thread.title: Northern Lights could be visible from UK tonight – this is how to spot them
thread.title_full: Northern Lights could be visible from UK tonight – this is how to spot them

title: Northern Lights could be visible from UK tonight – this is how to spot them
text:
GETTY LIGHTS: You'll be able to see the Northern Lights in parts of the UK tonight 
Forget going to Iceland, Sweden or Norway – stargazers across certain parts of the UK managed to glimpse the spectacular Northern Lights over the last few nights. 
The Aurora Borealis dazzled parts of the country, including North East England and Scotland, last night. The spectacular light show revealed itself from Loch Lomond to Dunbar and as far north as Shetland. 
If you're lucky you might be able to see the awe-inspiring dancing lights from Britain tonight, so keep your eyes peeled. 
However it's very dependant on the weather so keep your eyes glued to the weather guide – rain and cloud will prevent it from being visible. Northern Lights create beautiful sky show for thousands Friday, 8th April 2016 The stunning Aurora Borealis, aka Northern Lights, as seen from the UK, Alaska and various other places. 1 / 31 Caters News Agency The Northern Lights above the Steese Highway, Fairbanks in Alaska 
The Aurora Borealis, form when charged particles from the sun penetrate the earth's magnetic field and collide with atoms and molecules to create bursts of light. 
The Northern Lights are is most commonly spotted in Norway and Sweden but recently solar activity has been increasing with the light shows occasionally visible in the skies above the UK. 
"The beauty of nature and the Northern Lights is it's difficult to predict," Jonny Cooper, Director of Off the Map Travel says. 
"We would recommend finding a spot with clear dark skies away from any pollution, look north and be patient. 
"It just takes a break in the cloud to see the Aurora and it's well worth the adventure." Related videos
